metadata.title: Rett Syndrome  Communication Disorders
anatomical location body part affected: Cardiac, neurologic, motor, and speech systems
description: Rett syndrome (RTT) is a neurodevelopmental disease affecting the white matter of the brain. RTT occurs in approximately 1/10,000 females, with onset typically between the ages of 6 months and 2 years.(1,2) RTT leads to cardiac, neurologic, motor, and speech and language complications and impairments.(3) RTT in males is very rare, as it is usually lethal to the male fetus.(1) Late-onset  RTT (after age 3 years) is uncommon and usually is less severe, with better preservation of motor and speech skills.(3) A milder variant of RTT is known as the preserved speech variant (PSV) or Zappella variant of RTT (Z-RTT).(4,49,50,51) Two other of the more common variants of RTT are the early seizure variant (marked by the presence of severe seizures during the first year of life) and the congenital variant (marked by no apparent period of normal development and microcephaly documented at birth).(49,50) Most research confirms that RTT is not a degenerative disease.(5) RTT was previously considered an autism spectrum disorder (ASD); however, it is now a distinct, separate diagnosis.(6,48) Though there are over 200 different mutations or Rett “variants,” four specific mutations account for most cases of RTT(1)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Signs and symptoms vary in occurrence and severity based on the specific genetic mutation present(7)

Individuals with RTT demonstrate typical development until about 6 months of age, with a normal perinatal period, in which there is normal or near-normal  psychomotor development(8,9) –Some research suggests that signs of RTT (such as early hand stereotypies with slow fidgety movements, idiosyncratic vocalizations, asymmetric eye opening, and abnormal facial expressions) are often present even in the first months of life(11)

After approximately 6 months of typical development, there is a period of rapid deterioration of mental, motor, and language skills, and the following signs begin to be evident: –Main criteria (at least 3 of the following 6 required for diagnosis)(12) -Physical signs -Microcephaly(3) -Although children with RTT have normal head circumference at birth, their head circumference does not grow at the normal rate -Speech and language signs -Slowed or regression of expressive/receptive language development(3) -Language development does not usually progress beyond 1-word  utterances(13,14) -In some cases, children exhibit delayed communication development even before the onset of other signs and symptoms of RTT(13) -More commonly, speech is normally developing until speech production begins to regress(3) -Approximately 50% of children with RTT use meaningful words before the age of 20 months(14) -Post onset, receptive and expressive language is severely delayed, with the child being able to use short sentences (2–3 words) at most(14) -Most individuals with RTT regress and cease to use verbal communication altogether(14) -Average language development for individuals with RTT is at the level of 1–2 years of age(14) -Some nonverbal children are able to make meaningful choices, use a “want” symbol, or use eye gaze to indicate a request(15) -Social communication – loss of social communication skills(12) -Disinterest in social interactions and loss of social skills, although such skills are sometimes reacquired later in development(2,8,16) -Social anxiety(1) -Deterioration of motor function(12) -Slowed or regression of fine motor development and hand skills -Uncoordinated gait and trunk movements, ataxia, and apraxia(6,8,17) -Rigidity and bradykinesia in some older patients(18) -Behavioral features – wringing of hands/stereotyped hand movements(6,16) -RTT disease profile/RTT stage development (see description below of the four stages of RTT)(12,19)  –Supportive criteria -Physical signs -Growth retardation(12) -Small feet(20) -Waking hyperventilation (i.e., periods of excessive breathing that can lead to dizziness; numbness of toes, fingers, and lips; confusion; and weakness)(8) -Scoliosis(3,12,17) -Disturbed ambulation(7) -Gastrointestinal dysfunctions(12,18) -Gastroesophageal reflux, esophagitis, and gallbladder dysfunction are common(12) -Reduced life span(12,18) -Speech, communication, and swallowing functions -Apraxia of speech(21) -Swallowing/feeding issues – reduced oral movements, reduced lip closure, delayed pharyngeal swallow, breathing disturbances during feeding(17,21) -Patient might be malnourished as a result of swallowing difficulties and have difficulty gaining weight(17) -Aspiration risk is high in approximately 15% of patients with RTT(21) -Hearing loss in 27–35%  of females with RTT(22) -Higher prevalence of sensorineural hearing loss than conductive/mixed hearing loss(22) -Risk of early onset of high-frequency  hearing loss(22) -Prevalence of hearing loss is increased in those treated with anticonvulsant medications(22) -Respiratory -Breathing issues, hyperventilation, and apnea(17,18,21,23) -Brainstem immaturity causing labile breathing rhythms, reduction in baseline cardiac vagal tone signs, and vacant spells with involuntary movements, long breath holds, and shallow breathing(24) -Cardiac -Elevated risk of cardiac arrest(12) -Bradycardia(12) -Cold extremities (due to poor blood flow)(12,25) -Neurologic -Seizures(12) -Abnormal EEG findings(12,18) -Spastic paraparesis and quadriparesis (later stages of RTT)(23) -Dementia(12) -Intellectual disability/cognitive impairment(26) -Behavioral -Teeth grinding(9,21) -Agitation(17) -Autistic-like  behavior such as hand stereotypies, loss of social communication, and reduced eye contact(23) -Eye pointing(27) -Sleeping difficulties(9) -Lower levels of irritability, hyperactivity, and inappropriate speech behaviors than control groups of individuals with isolated intellectual disability(28) -Unmotivated sudden laughter or screaming(19)  -Self-abusive  behavior(12) –Exclusionary criteria -Other metabolic or heredodegenerative disorder(20) -Acquired neurological disorder due to head trauma (i.e., brain injury) or infection(20,50) -Perinatally acquired brain damage(20,50) -Intrauterine growth retardation(20) -Optic atrophy or retinopathy(20) -Severely abnormal psychomotor development during first 6 months of life(50)

There are 4 stages of RTT(3,10,26) –Early onset – stage I (6–18  months of age)(26) -Withdrawal from surroundings and demonstration of delay in speech and motor skill acquisition –Rapid destructive or regression stage – stage II (1–3 years of age)(26) -“Autistic-like”  withdrawal, social-emotional instability, stereotyped hand movements, and a loss of previously acquired skills(54) –Pseudostationary or plateau stage – stage III (preschool to school years)(26) -Disease stabilizes, brain growth continues, social interactions improve, mood changes are evident, autistic behavior is minimized, and some recovery of receptive and expressive speech is seen –Late motor deterioration stage – stage IV (adolescent/teen years)(3,8,26) -Characterized by a loss of ambulation, progressive scoliosis, difficulties chewing and swallowing, muscle weakness, and loss of receptive and expressive speech -By late childhood, children usually are nonverbal and nonambulatory(8)

The preserved speech variant (PSV), or Zappella variant, of RTT (Z-RTT)  affects 2–4%  of females with RTT and varies somewhat from classic RTT(25) –Microcephaly, microsomia (small stature), and low weight are less common(4) –Breathing irregularities, cold extremities, and gastrointestinal disturbances are less common(4,25) –Milder scoliosis and kyphosis (curving of the spine leading to hunchback or slouching posture)(4) –Milder intellectual impairments (as compared to individuals with classic RTT)(4) –Although the four stages of the disease are the same as in classic RTT, individuals with Z-RTT  have a delayed stage I and stage IV and might not progress to stage IV until they are over 18 years of age(4) –Hand stereotypies are often less intense and/or less evident(4) –Hand use is better(4) –Less frequent seizures(4) –During stage III, patients recover some language abilities(25) -Receptive and expressive language skills improve, ranging from single words to complex phrases. Language is recovered around age 6 years(4) -Authors of a case study of a female in whom Z-RTT  was diagnosed at age 3 years documented her developmental profile until the age of 11 and, despite some recovery of language abilities following the regression stage, reported restricted gestural repertoire, morpho-syntactic  and socio-pragmatic  deficits in language development, and the presence of echolalia which interrupted the flow of speech(51) –Speech has a sing-song  quality; many patients love music and singing(25) –Some children with Z-RTT  do not regress (but also do not further develop) in language and motor skills(29) –Autistic-like  behavior such as hand stereotypies and reduced eye contact is evident(4) –Since many of the signs of RTT are so mild in individuals with Z-RTT,  it may be more difficult to diagnose(4,29) –There is a higher rate of familial cases of Z-RTT  as compared to classic RTT(25)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: RTT is a sporadically occurring, X-linked  disorder caused by a mutation in the MECP2  gene(1)

Mutations of the MECP2  gene inhibit synthesis of methyl cytosine-binding  protein 2 (MeCP2), a protein found in the brainthat has a role in motor control, emotional control, emotional development, and early brain development.(8,23) Insufficientquantities or abnormal forms of the protein can negatively affect other genes(26)
pathogenesis: The underlying molecular pathology of the disorder is unknown(18)
Studies suggest that RTT might result from improper development or maintenance of synaptic connections in the brain andneuronal maturation failure during a time of rapid brain development(12)
RTT is not a degenerative disease. While some motor and communication skills do worsen with time, other skills plateau orimprove as the patient grows older and with intervention(5)
risk factors: Female sex (it is very rare for a male to present with RTT)–Males with MECP2  mutations typically exhibit signs and symptoms that are different from those exhibited by individualswith RTT (i.e., rapidly progressive encephalopathy, severe developmental delay, spastic paraparesis, and intellectualdisability)(12)

overall contraindications precautions: The clinician must be aware of the cultural and linguistic backgrounds of the patient and patient’s family, as these can affect assessment and the treatment protocol

The clinician should involve the parents as well as the patient’s teachers and other therapists (collaborative model) in the assessment and treatment process for more accurate information and best results

The clinician should observe the patient in a variety of settings as well as conduct interviews with parents and caregivers to become aware of the patient’s level of communicative functioning and to develop appropriate communication and language goals
The clinician must be aware of the patient’s pain and tolerance level as well as attention span, anxiety level, and any other behavioral issues during assessment and treatment
The clinician should complete a thorough review of the medical history prior to conducting a speech-language  evaluation or treatment

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -What signs or symptoms of RTT are exhibited by the patient? When was RTT diagnosed? (Diagnosis is usually tentative until age 2 years)(13) -What is the child’s current stage of RTT?

course of treatment.medical management: Which physicians follow and care for the patient? What is the patient’s general health status and issues? Review medical records, as well as any previous therapy records, especially those pertaining to communication development. What is the child’s ear health status?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Various medications may be prescribed to reduce symptoms, including carbamazepine (to improve alertness), valproic acid and lamotrigine (to control seizures), and naltrexone (to modify irregular breathing)(8,12)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Following initial observation of the signs and symptoms of RTT, usual tests for this condition are the following:

EEG: EEG of RTT patients in the later stages is characterized by being slow, having focal epileptiform discharges and rare spikes or sharp waves when awake, and a progressive loss of sleep characteristics(18)

Cranial CT and MRI: Findings from these tests are normal in the initial stages of the disease, but later atrophy of both cerebral hemispheres is found along with reduction of volume in the caudate nucleus(18)
Laboratory tests: A physician will order laboratory studies of blood, urine, CSF, and lysosomal enzymes(18)

Genetic testing and gene mapping can determine what mutation of the MECP2  gene is responsible for the disease. Certain mutations of the gene are linked to specific signs and symptoms, and knowing the type of mutation helps predict the likelihood of developing or retaining various skills such as hand use, walking, and speech abilities and provide information regarding the likely clinical profile of the patient(1,30)
Chromosome analysis and molecular probing is also important for ruling out Angelman syndrome in the differential diagnosis(12)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Inquire about factors that appear to improve or worsen communication ability (e.g., music, lights, noise, time of day)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, regressing skills, improving, advancing symptoms). See Signs and symptoms , above
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, ability to sleep during the day (nap)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document patient’s respiratory status. Does the patient require supplemental oxygen, tracheostomy tube, or mechanical ventilation?Document any behavioral symptoms that indicate a psychosocial disturbance. At 1 to 4 years of age, children with RTT syndrome lose their ability to speak and may scream or cry without provocation. At 2 to 10 years of age, children with RTT syndrome have been reported to be less irritable and may show an improvement in alertness and communication skills.(20,21) Refer to psychologist or social work as indicated -Caregiver burden usually is high for caregivers of children with RTT syndrome. The RTT Caregiver Inventory has been shown to be a valid and reliable measure of physical, social, and emotional burden on caregivers for individuals with RTT syndrome(55) -Caregivers/parents of children with RTT syndrome might benefit from referral for counseling servicesDocument results of audiological evaluations. Hearing loss occurs in 27% to 35% of females with RTT(22) -Higher prevalence of sensorineural hearing loss than conductive/mixed hearing loss(22) -Increased risk of early onset of high-frequency hearing loss(22) -Prevalence of hearing loss is increased in those treated with anticonvulsant medications(22) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Ask about speech and language development. Document if any previous speech/language testing has been completed; if it has, review past reports. Ask about delayed speech/language development, plateaus in development, and regression of language and/or motor skills
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient’s family/caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, hearing loss, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs). See Medications for current illness , above

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient attend daycare, preschool, or school? If so, what type of support is in place during school hours? Does the patient interact with peers? Does the child show an interest in the use of toys? Document patient’s likes and dislikes as well as interests (e.g., music and singing)(29)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document what type of adaptive equipment the patient is using, such as augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) devices, hearing aids, or glasses. Ask patient and/or family members about the effect of communication deficits on the patient’s participation in social, educational, and occupational activities. Obtain any relevant occupational or physical therapy evaluations or notes. There is some research to suggest that preservation of motor functions in individuals with RTT might be associated with better preservation of speech skills(3)
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members, group home). Identify if there are barriers to age-appropriate  independence in the home; any modifications necessary? With whom does the patient communicate? How does the patient communicate at home and/or at school?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Determine if patient uses AAC devices. If so, what kind? How does the device impact communication functioning? Common alternative forms of communication include eye gaze, pictures, and other forms of assisted communication; gestures; facial expressions; and sounds or vocalizations with specific meaning(21)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading) –Speech -Complete a phonetic inventory and assess articulation accuracy in single words if patient produces words and/or phrasesThe following are examples of standardized and nonstandardized testing measures that may be used to assess expressive/receptive language abilities -Clinical Linguistic and Auditory Milestone Scale (CLAMS) provides normative data on milestones achieved between birth and 2 years of age(13) -Most children with RTT meet early communication milestones such as being alert, smiling, cooing, babbling, and saying “mama/dada” indiscriminately. Children who develop RTT rarely are able to say “mama/dada” discriminately, use first words, or follow one-step  commands and rarely have a vocabulary of more than 3–4 single words(13) -Infant/Toddler Checklist in the Communication and Symbolic Behavior Scales Developmental Profile can be used to evaluate skills such as intentional eye gaze, gestures, sounds, and understanding(32) -The Inventory of Potential Communication Acts (IPCA) assessment can be used to assess communication skills for both typical and atypical variants of RTT(15,52) -The Nonspeech Test can be used to evaluate expressive and receptive communication and to assign a language age score(15)(11) -slow, fidgety movements -high pain tolerance -bursts of abnormal facial expression -Test ability to use gestures, follow simple directions, understand and use simple vocabulary words, and identify body parts -Parent questionnaires are helpful in determining if and what kind of oral or alternative communication is used by the
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Using a checklist or parent/caregiver questionnaire, document presence and/or frequency of abnormal behavioral and emotional features(28) -Hand stereotypies -Rapid and heavy breathing -Autistic-like  behavior such as reduced eye contact, reduced interest in social interactions, and stereotypies -Indifference to or little interest in both persons and objects -Patients with Z-RTT  are more likely to take pleasure in communication and even prefer persons to objects(30) -Repeatedly putting hands in mouth -Poor eye contact -Holding of breath -Grinding of teeth -Expressionless face -Inappropriate laughter -Screaming fits -Insensitivity to pain -Inappropriate fear in unfamiliar situations -Withdrawn behavior -Anxiety, distress, frustration -Low mood -Staring at lights -Self-abusive  behavior with hands –Due to impaired motor and communication skills, cognitive function is difficult to assess using standardized measures(12) -Parent/caregiver interview, patient observations, and assessments that rely on visual response only can provide information about cognitive level and adaptive skills (feeding, dressing, and toileting)(12) -Level of cognitive functioning usually is determined following thorough psychiatric or neuropsychiatric examination by a psychologist or psychiatrist(19) -IQ testing -Mental scale of the Bayley Scales of Infant Development (BSID-II).  This scale gathers information on cognitive, language, social, and personal development and describes behavior qualitatively(31)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: RTT leading to profound communication and language disorders
assessment plan of care.rule out: The signs and symptoms of RTT are similar to those of various other disorders. In individuals with Z-RTT, especially those who have mild signs and symptoms, Angelman syndrome, ASD, or non-syndromic intellectual disability may be mistakenly diagnosed.(30) The physician will do a differential diagnosis to rule out the following: ASD(23) Cerebral palsy(23) Prader-Willi  syndrome Encephalitis West syndrome Tuberous sclerosis Phenylketonuria Spinocerebellar degeneration Neuroaxonal dystrophy Lennox-Gastaut  syndrome Psychosis(23) Angelman syndrome(10) Other neurogenic diseases(23) Klinefelter syndrome in males with signs and symptoms of RTT(10)
prognosis: Life expectancy is reduced, and many patients die between adolescence and age 30. As many as 67% of patients live beyond age 30.(6,12,23) Common causes of death are apnea and seizures(6)

RTT is a lifelong disease but not a degenerative one. As such, various forms of therapy can be effective in improving and maintaining motor skills, functional living skills, and cognitive, behavioral, and communication abilities(5)
There is no cure for RTT
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to physician, audiologist, psychologist, dentist, occupational therapist, school/ educational personnel, and physical therapist as needed
other considerations: Goals for treatment include symptom relief such as physical therapy for muscular issues, medications to reduce occurrences and severity of seizures, behavioral therapy for self-coping,  and speech therapy for improved communication skills(2)
Physical, occupational, and speech therapies are recommended in order to address and improve the patient’s functional abilities(23)
treatment summary: There is a lack of randomized controlled studies regarding the efficacy of rehabilitative treatments to improve communication skills in patients with RTT

Feeding –In a study conducted in Sweden on eating proficiency in individuals with RTT, researchers found that up to 63% of subjects required food consistency to be adjusted in order to chew properly(21)

Oral motor treatment –Oral motor treatment such as mirror work, blowing bubbles, licking up on a spoon or popsicle stick, tongue clicking, and tension exercises by an SLP might be beneficial for treating teeth grinding(21) –Referral to a dentist might be indicated, especially in the case of teeth grinding

Music therapy –Music therapy might temporarily motivate patients to interact socially with others and may temporarily diminish hand stereotypies -Based on the results of a research study conducted in Japan of 3 children with RTT (aged 4, 5, and 6 years)(35) -SLPs can implement musical activities in their therapy (e.g., playing the piano or other instruments together, taking turns playing instruments) –Music therapy can encourage communication and learning in patients with RTT(36) -Based on the results of a case study of a female with RTT -During music therapy, the subject was found to demonstrate turn taking, vocalization, anticipation of the desired event, and understanding of cause and effect and object permanence -Weaknesses of the study include subject number (N = 1) and lack of statistical data(36) -Based on a study of 7 girls with RTT conducted in Norway(37) -The subjects were able to indicate choice using eye gaze or nose or hand pointing during musical activities -The accuracy and rate of making choices improved among the subjects during musical activities -The authors also suggest that the relationship between the clinician and the participant is very important and that it is vital that a participant feel comfortable with his or her therapist -With the proper intervention, fluent nonverbal communication (such as the use of mutual imitation, responsiveness to playful teasing, use of basic oral, vocal, and gestural expressions, as well as joint attention and eye gaze) is a realistic goal for nonverbal individuals with RTT.(38) Using humorous interactions and music or singing in therapy, a clinician is more likely to be successful in eliciting turn taking, imitation, joint attention, and vocalization.(38) A “mother-infant” model was described by a researcher and developmental psychologist in 1993(39) in which the goal of the interaction is to develop social play in a spontaneous, enjoyable, and naturalistic manner. Researchers in Scotland note that this model has been and can be used in therapy, and that the naturalistic and biologically based intervention might be appropriate for use with children with RTT(38)

Sensory-motor  rehabilitation –Developmental, Individual Differences, Relationship-Based Approach, also known as Greenspan’s Floortime Model, can be used by clinicians to guide patients with RTT through six developmental levels and to involve them in developmentally appropriate interactions. Much focus is placed on helping the patient be self-regulated,  calm, and focused before he or she interacts with others. In addition, the therapist is encouraged to respond to all intentional and meaningful modes of communication from the patient(40) –Sensory-motor  rehabilitation may improve language, motor, cognitive, and behavioral skills in patients with RTT(41) -Based on a case study of a female with RTT who began a rehabilitation program at age 5 -The treatment program was based on Piaget’s cognitive development theory  -The patient underwent 3 years of visual-motor coordination training as well as a sensory-motor rehabilitation program -After treatment, the subject was able to respond to her name, understand 58 words (compared to 2 words pretreatment), use gestures, play a game, demonstrate symbolic play, and choose requested objects and pictures (discrimination tasks). These were all skills that were deficient pretreatment –SLPs and behavioral therapists need to be trained in sensory motor rehabilitation or visual-motor  coordination in order to implement these models in therapy with the patient –Functional communication training -Authors of a preliminary study conducted in the United States reported that functional communication training in 3 individuals with RTT resulted in positive changes, including novel communicative acts. The 3 females in the study were ages 15, 27, and 47, and all had classic RTT. Functional communication training involved training the participants to use a switch to indicate functional needs. The switch was placed close to each participant’s dominant hand and researchers used positive reinforcement when the participants used the switch to indicate a desire (turning on the TV). Each participant responded quickly to the functional communication training and at the end of 18 sessions was more likely to request that the TV be turned on with the use of the switch versus whining or other undesired behavior. Researchers recommended functional communication training in larger populations of patients with RTT to determine efficacy(53) –Structured overinterpretation, structured total communication, and multimodal cueing -Researchers recommend training eye gaze for functional communication, as well as training teachers and caregivers how to understand and interpret communication attempts. In a study conducted in Israel, researchers found that stereotypical hand motions of 8 females with RTT increased during interruptions in given activities, suggesting that study subjects were attempting to use the hand stereotypies to communicate. These behaviors were found to be consistent by repeated trials, but it was difficult to ascertain if they were intentional. This study was limited by small subject number and inability to unequivocally demonstrate that subjects intentionally used eye gaze or hand stereotypies to communicate(15) -Research is conflicting regarding the efficacy of increasing communication opportunities for children with RTT to improve communication -Improving existing communication attempts as well as increasing the number of communication opportunities for children with RTT might be more effective than training children with RTT to use an AAC device(42,43) -Multimodal cueing (such as verbal and tactile cues) helps maintain the child’s level of alertness and gain the child’s attention -Extra response time is warranted for children with RTT -Caregivers and teachers can reinforce language acts by acknowledging all communication attempts made by the child -In a study conducted in Australia of 3 nonverbal girls with RTT that used video recordings to observe and analyze teacher/student interactions, researchers found that while increased communication opportunities provided by the caregivers did not significantly increase patient responses, all 3 subjects responded to interactions that required a response. This might indicate that some patients with RTT can understand the intent of spoken language (as the subjects did seem to understand that by initiating communication, the caregiver was expecting a response)(44)

AAC can be used to teach patients to make choices, indicate preference, and increase communication skills –Van Acker’s device employs a touch-sensitive  computer screen and animated graphics to allow a patient to request food and other basic needs. In a study conducted in the United States with 3 individuals with RTT(ages 5, 6, and 11 years), researchers found that all of the subjects learned to discriminate and make consistent choices using this device. Weakness of the study includes small subject number(45) –AAC devices such as the Unity 45 One Hit on a Vanguard II (Prentke Romich Company, Wooster, OH), Specs switches (AbleNet Inc., Roseville, MN), single switch devices, and BIGmack Communicators (AbleNet Inc., Roseville, MN) for yes/no answers; LITTLE Step-by-Step  Communicator (AbleNet Inc., Roseville, MN) and Mini-Coms  (Enabling Devices, Hastings-on-Hudson,  NY) for making choices; Jellybean switches (AbleNet Inc., Roseville, MN), Microlight switches (AbleNet Inc., Roseville, MN); and picture communication symbols to make choices and requests and to convey information. When training patients to use a new device, it is important to use the device in a highly motivating activity, and one in which the patient is allowed to direct the activity. Case studies have shown that individuals with RTT can make choices, play games, and express detailed requests using AAC. It is important to note that more complicated devices may be difficult to use for individuals with apraxia or poor hand strength or control(46) -In a study involving 2 girls with RTT (ages 12 and 17), researchers found that after an intensive therapy program provided 3 times per week for 5 months, quantity and quality of the subjects’ responses were improved when they used AAC.(46) The subjects were taught to use aided communication devices to signal “want” to request a preferred item. Before treatment, the percentage of independent responses was approximately 30%; following treatment, the percentage  of independent responses increased to 57.5% in 1 subject and to 87.5% in the other. Limitations of the study include small subject number(46)

Communication partner training –In a study conducted in the United States with 4 girls with RTT (ages 3 to 7 years) and their communication partners, researchers found that communication partner training resulted in increased communicative initiations by the girls with RTT(47) -Researchers used the context of mealtime to implement communication strategies; communication partners were 2 classroom teachers, 1 classroom aide, and 1 SLP -Each communication partner was trained in 3 to 4 communication strategies to implement during mealtimes with the child with RTT, and their interactions were videotaped and analyzed -The specific strategies trained were tailored to the individual needs of the dyad; however, all communication partners were encouraged to increase their wait time between bites and after asking questions of the girls to allow the girls to communicate desire for another bite or to respond to questions posed -Communication partners were taught to observe the girls for eye gaze, head turns, body movements toward food, vocalizations, and use of low-tech  AAC devices and to actively respond to these communicative behaviors -Researchers’ analysis of the videotapes found that as the communication partner purposefully changed his or her behavior, there were noticeable changes in the child’s behavior as well, namely increased requests for more food and increased initiation of communication by the child . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Lack of communication, inability to make request or choicePatient will make requests, choicesMusic therapy

Use motivating musical activities such as joint piano playing, the playing of other instruments, or even taped music as opportunities for patients to indicate preference/make choices using eye gaze, language, or AAC. For example, the patient may indicate a desire for the caregiver or therapist to continue playing the instrument using eye gaze or AAC
SLP can collaborate with a musical therapist in treating a child with RTT

Patient might learn to indicate desires through the use of eye gaze with prompts, eye gaze without prompts, or indicating by the use of a switchMusic therapy may diminish hand stereotypies(35) and promote turn taking, understanding of cause and effect, and vocalization(36)Teach parents/ caregivers how to incorporate musical activities in the home environment  Reduced communication and interaction skillsImprove ability to make choices and other communication functionsCommunication aides – AAC/aided communication

Patients can be trained to point/use eye gaze/ hand over graphic communication (photographs, pictures) and actual objects to signal immediate needs. Focus on training patients to choose between a few objects or activities(27)
Use visual communication aides such as basic symbols from a communication board or switches to indicate desire and preference(46) and to improve communication
Van Acker’s touch- sensitive screen and graphics system can be effectively used by patients to request food and basic needs(45)
Clinicians should train use of device during highly motivating activities(46)

Symbolic requests through aided communication can be used in conjunction with interpretation of eye gaze and idiosyncratic gesturesCommunication aids such as pointing, eye gaze, hand over hand graphic communication with cues, hand over hand graphic communication without cues should be introduced as early as possible. Maintain use on a consistent basis _ _ Patients with RTT do have ability to learn and retain learning over time(37) _ _ With intensive treatment, patients can make significant progress(46)Family and caregivers should know how to use communication aid so that it can work functionally for the patient(21)  Reduced communication and interaction skills on the part of the patient, reduced ability for the caregiver to understand the behaviors of the patientImprove spontaneous communication on the part of the patient, improve quality of life of the patient, improve ability for the caregiver to understand and interpret the behaviors of the patientStructured overinterpretation and structured total communication   (27)
Parents and caregivers learn to interpret needs, wants, and interests through the patient’s behaviors (such as eye gaze)
Stereotypical hand movements might be used by patients as a form of communication. Caregivers should be trained how to interpret such gestures(15)
Clinician and parents should respond to all intentional and meaningful modes of conversation(46)

Structured total communication aims to teach patients to use objects, signs, and photographs to express their needs and wantsStructured overinterpretation has not been found to lead to independent and spontaneous communication. Nevertheless, it can be used to help caregivers understand and interpret the needs and interests of the patient and improve quality of life(27)Provide patient and family/caregivers with strategies to interpret/ over interpret behaviors and actions of the patient (such as eye gaze)  Poor communication, play skills, joint attentionImprove communication and languageSensory-motor rehabilitation   (41)

Based on Piaget’s cognitive development stages, this type of therapy incorporates visual motor coordination training as well as sensory- motor training in combination with communication goals _ Sensory motor training includes:
Visual attention and hand-eye coordination
Increasing awareness about relations in space
Teaching object permanence
Means–ends relation and operational casualty
Verbal comprehension (patient is asked to touch preferred object)

Gestural imitation and use of gestures in communicationStudy found that after 3 years, subject demonstrated improved vocabulary, joint attention, symbolic play, and choice making, as well as improved motor skills, cognitive skills, and language skills(41)Parent education is important in order to help train joint attention and develop vocabulary in the home/child’s natural environment Poor attention, alertness, reduced communication attemptsIncrease responses Multimodal cueing (44)
Allow child extra response time
Give verbal, visual, and tactile cues to gain patient’s attention and maintain alertness
Acknowledge all communication attemptsProgression will vary according to individual patient needs and goals _Parent education and follow-up at home is recommended .

improved functional abilities in communi: Infant/Toddler Checklist in the Communication and Symbolic Behavior Scales Developmental Profile

maintenance or prevention: RTT is a genetic, lifelong disease for which there is no cure. However, therapy and treatment can reduce and manage symptoms and improve quality of life
Despite the fact that chance of reoccurrence in families is less than 1%,parents of a child with RTT should be offered genetic counseling during subsequent pregnancies(2,12)
patient education: For more information on RTT for caregivers and families of RTT patients, seehttps://www.ninds.nih.gov/Disorders/All-Disorders/Rett-Syndrome-Information-Page Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
